author: mklement0
body:
Note: The fact that `Get-ChildItem` and `Get-Item` do not find hidden items with _literal_ paths even without `-Force` - in contrast with other filesystem cmdlets such as `Test-Path` and `Resolve-Path`, see #6502 and #6501 - is problematic in itself, but that's the behavior we're stuck with.

This issue is about a particular inconsistency in the context of the current behavior.

# Steps to reproduce

On Linux or macOS (does not happen on Windows).

```powershell
mkdir -p .tf  # create temporary hidden folder
{ Get-Item .tf -EA Stop } | Should -Throw
{ Get-Item .tf/ -EA Stop } | Should -Throw
rmdir .tf
```

Note that Get*Child*-Item, by contrast, consistently finds hidden directories by _literal_ path even without `-Force`, with or without a trailing `/` - arguably, another inconsistency.

# Expected behavior

No output, because both tests should pass, given that hidden dir. `.tf` shouldn't be found without `-Force`, with or without trailing `/`.

# Actual behavior

```none
Expected an exception, to be thrown, but no exception was thrown.
```

That is, the second command targeting `.tf` with a trailing `/` unexpectedly succeeded (found the item).

# Environment data

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```none
PowerShell Core v7.0.0-preview.2 (7.0.0-preview.2) on macOS 10.14.6
PowerShell Core v7.0.0-preview.2 (7.0.0-preview.2) on Ubuntu 18.04.2 LTS
```
title: Get-Item finds hidden directories even without -Force when a slash is appended
